lines.text: Is true. The English despise men who are half drunk. I must make myself completely drunk.
I must allow myself to say, ma'am, that your uncle had better not attempt to kick an Englishman downstairs.
You want me to kick you upstairs?
Young man. It is not better to be drunk than sober. But it is happier.
You have no hearts, you English! Heart! Heart!
[slaps the right side of his chest]
Pardon, your highness. Your heart is on the other side.
Darling! A true Russian has a heart on both sides!
Have you had a college education, darling? I have.
Certainly. I am a bachelor of arts.
Once she know you are a bachelor, Catherine will supply the arts.
In Russia, a gentleman has no scruples. In Russia we face facts.
In England a gentleman never faces any facts if they are unpleasant.
Why not merely get rid of him? Send him to Siberia!
Don't be stupid, Potemkin. He's English. He would have the place colonized within a year.
Your majesty, would you be a little angel mother and tie me up again?
Charles...
[she ties him up like a trussed chicken]
I really am most awfully grateful.
I didn't know they did this sort of thing in England.
Let me help you, captain. If only to show you that a Russian savage can be kinder than an English one. Though I'm sorry to say that I'm German.
Don't call me 'darling'. I've been called 'darling' all morning.
By who?
By everybody. By the most unatterable swine. And if we don't leave this abominable city now - do you hear, now! - I shall be called 'darling' by the empress.
[last lines]
If I could only have had him for my... for my...
For your lover?
No. For my museum.
Varinka, go look through keyhole in imperial bedchamber and bring back word whether empress is awake yet.
I do not look through keyholes.
You have been badly brought up, my little darling. Would any lady or gentleman walk into a room unannounced without first looking through keyhole?
